questions.text: A 10-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department by his parents because of a dull persistent headache that began this morning. He has nausea and has vomited twice. Over the past four days, the patient has had left-sided ear pain and fever, but his parents did not seek medical attention. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. He is at the 45th percentile for height and 40th percentile for weight. He appears irritable. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 69/min, and blood pressure is 114/76 mm Hg. The pupils are equal and reactive to light. Lateral gaze of the left eye is limited. Otoscopy of the left ear shows an erythematous bulging tympanic membrane. There is no nuchal rigidity. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Clindamycin and cefazolin are not appropriate antibiotics for treating suspected intracranial infection because they have relatively poor CNS penetration. Metronidazole and ceftriaxone are typically used instead. Moreover, antibiotic therapy without prior surgical intervention is insufficient for the treatment of most brain abscesses because antibiotics cannot effectively penetrate the abscess cavity.

B) INCORRECT:

Myringotomy is not routinely indicated for AOM and is only considered if the patient has recurrent or treatment-refractory AOM or chronic otitis media. Moreover, this procedure is not the most important initial step in the management of a patient with features that suggest an intracranial abscess.
Image Description:

The procedure can be performed under local or general anesthesia; general anesthesia is usually required for children. An operating microscope is preferred, although the procedure can be performed using a handheld operating otoscope.

1. A radial incision is made in the anterior-inferior quadrant of the pars tensa using a myringotomy blade.
2. Alligator forceps are used to insert the tympanostomy tube. Short-term tubes (I) are designed to self-extrude after approximately one year, whereas long-term tubes (II) have a longer flange that prevents extrusion.
3. A curved or angled pick can be used to facilitate correct placement.

C) CORRECT:

Patients with suspected intracranial abscess should promptly undergo cranial imaging with a contrast-enhanced CT scan or MRI to identify the size, location, and number of abscesses to guide further management. Treatment of an intracranial abscess consists of urgent abscess evacuation to decompress the cranial cavity and identify causative pathogens. Patients should also be given early empiric antibiotic therapy with metronidazole and ceftriaxone, and vancomycin should be added if a staphylococcal infection is suspected. Antibiotic therapy alone may be attempted in rare instances when the brain abscess is small (< 2.5 cm), uncomplicated, and has a known pathogen.
Image Description:

Cranial MRI (with contrast, axial view)

An oval lesion can be seen in the left temporal lobe, with ring-like contrast enhancement (green ring) and central necrosis (green overlay). The perifocal edema (white overlay) that is visible corresponds to the lesion. Differential diagnoses include an abscess, glioblastoma, and metastasis.

Diagnosis: abscess following advanced otitis media

D) INCORRECT:

Aspiration of the abscess through a burr hole is often the definitive treatment for an intracranial abscess but before performing this procedure, more information should be obtained on the size, location, and number of the intracranial abscesses to guide management and trajectory planning for the burr hole procedure.

A secondary decompressive craniectomy, which involves creating burr holes without trajectory planning, is only performed if the patient has increased ICP that is refractory to treatment of the underlying cause as well as subsequent medical therapy (e.g., controlled hyperventilation, hyperosmolar solutions).

E) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture is contraindicated in patients with features of elevated ICP because of the risk of brain herniation. Moreover, cerebrospinal fluid analysis is often normal in patients with an intracranial abscess and only shows abnormal findings if the abscess ruptures into the ventricular system or if the patient has concomitant meningitis or encephalitis. A different diagnostic step is much more important for this patient.
questions.hint: Headache, vomiting, and a focal neurological deficit (abducens nerve palsy) are consistent with increased intracranial pressure (ICP) secondary to an intracranial abscess, most likely as a complication of acute otitis media (AOM).

questions.text: An 11-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after he was found screaming and clutching his head. He has had nausea and occasional episodes of vomiting for 1 week, fever and left-sided headache for 2 weeks, and increasing tooth pain over the past 3 weeks. He has no history of ear or sinus infections. He is in moderate distress. Temperature is 38.7°C (101.7°F), pulse is 170/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 122/85 mm Hg. He is confused and only oriented to person. The pupils react sluggishly to light. Fundoscopic examination shows papilledema bilaterally. Extraocular movements are normal. Flexion of the neck causes hip flexion. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Viral meningitis can manifest with headache, fever, nausea/vomiting, and meningeal irritation. However, viral meningitis is less likely to manifest with signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., sluggish pupils, papilledema), altered mental status, and a 2-week history of focal left-sided headache, as seen in this patient.

B) INCORRECT:

Medulloblastoma can manifest with signs of increased intracranial pressure, including headaches, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema. Furthermore, a hemorrhage from a neoplasm could manifest with the sudden onset of a severe headache and altered mental status. However, peak incidence is during the first decade of life. In addition, since most medulloblastomas arise within the cerebellum, the lack of any cerebellar signs (e.g., gait ataxia, truncal instability, intention tremor, double vision) makes medulloblastoma less likely. Fever and a 3-week history of tooth pain suggest another etiology for this patient's symptoms.

C) INCORRECT:

A spontaneous subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) can manifest with severe headache, meningeal irritation, nausea, vomiting, and papilledema. Some patients with SAH may also develop a neurogenic fever. However, SAH in children is quite rare, and this patient's 3-week history of tooth pain and his 1-week history of malaise and fever suggest a different etiology for his condition.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus (HSV) encephalitis is the most common type of viral encephalitis and can manifest with headaches, fever, vomiting, and altered mental status. However, most patients present with focal neurological signs and seizures, which are absent in this patient. While focal inflammation of the temporal lobe (which is commonly affected in HSV encephalitis) can cause a slight elevation in intracranial pressure (ICP), this patient's sluggish pupils and bilateral papilledema suggest severely elevated ICP, which is not characteristic of HSV encephalitis. Finally, the subacute course of this patient's symptoms, with a history of toothache preceding focal left-sided headache, is not consistent with this diagnosis.

E) CORRECT:

This patient has developed a pyogenic brain abscess, most likely as a result of contiguous spread of bacteria from his dental caries. Brain abscesses often initially manifest with headache and fever, and, as the abscess grows within the limited space of the cranial vault, patients develop signs of elevated intracranial pressure, such as vomiting, papilledema, and altered mental status, as seen here. Rupture of the abscess, which likely occurred in this patient, can cause acute worsening of headache and signs of meningeal irritation, as demonstrated by the Brudzinski sign.

This patient should undergo brain imaging (CT or MRI) to confirm the diagnosis. Needle aspiration or excision of the abscess should also be performed, both for treatment and culture sample collection. Streptococcus and Bacteroides spp. are some of the most common pathogens isolated from brain abscesses caused by odontogenic infection.
Image Description:

MRI brain (T1-weighted; axial view; with contrast) of a 5-year-old girl presenting after a seizure.

An oval-shaped well-defined structure is located within the right temporal lobe. It demonstrates smooth ring enhancement with lack of enhancement centrally (red overlay). The lack of central enhancement is due to pus (green overlay). There is low signal surrounding this structure representing edema (blue overlay). Pus and edema appear hypointense, as fluid appears as low signal on T1-weigted images.

This is an example of a brain abscess. The main other differential is a primary brain lesion or a cystic metastasis. Other MRI sequences, along with clinical information, are required to help differentiate between these differentials.

F) INCORRECT:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis can develop as a result of contiguous spread of a dental infection into the cavernous sinus and manifest with headache, vomiting, fever, altered mental status, and bilateral papilledema. However, most patients present with unilateral periorbital edema and proptosis from increased pressure within the cavernous sinus, and palsies of the cranial nerves located within the cavernous sinus (III, IV, V1, V2, VI), none of which are seen here. In addition, meningeal irritation, as demonstrated by the Brudzinski sign in this patient, is not characteristic of cavernous sinus thrombosis.
questions.hint: An MRI of the brain would likely show an intraparenchymal lesion with peripheral ring enhancement.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 25 minutes after an episode of violent jerky movements of his hands and legs that lasted for 5 minutes. After the episode, he had difficulty conversing. For the past 10 days, he has had a left-sided headache and nausea. Apart from a history of recurrent ear infections treated with antibiotics, he reports no other personal or family history of serious illness. He works as an assistant at a veterinarian clinic. He appears ill and is oriented to place and person only. His temperature is 37.8°C (100.0°F), pulse is 102/min, and blood pressure is 112/78 mm Hg. Examination shows bilateral optic disc swelling. There is no lymphadenopathy. Muscle strength and tone are normal in all extremities. Deep tendon reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. Plantar reflex shows a flexor response bilaterally. Laboratory studies show a CD4+ T-lymphocyte count within the reference range. An MRI of the brain is shown. Intravenous mannitol and levetiracetam are administered. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although ciprofloxacin does have good CNS penetration, it decreases the seizure threshold and should therefore not be used in patients with a brain abscess. It is also not very effective against many gram-positive organisms such as Streptococci viridans group or MRSA, which are responsible for most cases of brain abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

A combination of metronidazole and a third-generation cephalosporin, such as cefotaxime, is one of the most commonly used antibiotic regimens for patients with a pyogenic brain abscess with an otogenic source. However, antibiotic treatment is typically initiated after a more invasive first-line procedure for diagnostic sampling has been performed. Antibiotic therapy alone may be attempted for small (< 2.5 cm) uncomplicated abscesses with a known pathogen. This patient with a large peripheral abscess and signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema) requires a more urgent management step before proceeding to antibiotic treatment, which should be initiated immediately after the first-line intervention.

C) CORRECT:

Almost all patients with brain abscesses require urgent drainage or excision to decompress the cranial cavity and to obtain a sample for culture. Following drainage of the abscess, intravenous empirical antibiotic therapy should be initiated with a third- or fourth-generation cephalosporin and metronidazole. Vancomycin should be added if infection with Staphylococcus is suspected (e.g., patients who develop a brain abscess following penetrating trauma or neurosurgery, or among patients with bacterial endocarditis). In addition to surgical drainage and antibiotics, patients with evidence of cerebral edema or increased ICP should be treated with a short course of glucocorticoids.

Antibiotic therapy without aspiration and surgical drainage may only be attempted in patients with a small (< 2.5 cm) uncomplicated brain abscess with a known pathogen.

D) INCORRECT:

Albendazole is used to treat helminthic infections such as cysticercosis. Patients with neurocysticercosis may present with seizures, headache, nausea, signs of increased intracranial pressure (e.g., papilledema), and a focal ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema. However, neurocysticercosis typically manifests with multiple, small (< 1 cm) lesions.

E) INCORRECT:

Pyrimethamine and sulfadiazine are used to treat patients with toxoplasmosis. This patient's occupation puts him at risk of toxoplasmosis because of his close contact with animals, especially cats. Cerebral toxoplasmosis may present with seizures, headache, nausea, and a ring-enhancing lesion with surrounding edema on cranial imaging. However, cerebral toxoplasmosis is almost exclusively seen in immunocompromised patients (e.g., patients with HIV infection) and usually manifests with multiple lesions at the brainstem, corticomedullary junction, pituitary gland, and basal ganglia, instead of a single focal lesion in the temporal lobe.
questions.hint: In a patient with a history of recurrent ear infections, the combination of headache, seizures, clinical features of increased intracranial pressure (nausea and papilledema), and an MRI showing a well-defined rim-enhancing mass with surrounding edema in the temporal lobe strongly indicates a pyogenic brain abscess. Fever may be mild in this condition because the infection and immune response are at first limited to the location of the abscess.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old man with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a headache and with left-arm numbness and tingling that, over the course of 2 days, have spread to his left face and left leg. Shortly before presentation, he also noted clumsiness with his left hand and difficulty walking, with a tendency to fall to the left. He denies any history of recreational drug use.
On examination, the patient is afebrile with a heart rate of 87 beats per minute and a blood pressure of 120/87 mm Hg. He has no head or spine tenderness, no neck stiffness, and no skin lesions. Cardiac examination reveals no murmurs.
Neurologic examination reveals a left-pronator drift, left lower facial weakness, and mild left weakness of ankle dorsiflexion. He has loss of sensation to light touch, vibration, and temperature on his entire left face, arm, and leg.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

A patient with a brain abscess typically presents with headache and focal neurologic symptoms. These patients may also have altered mental status. Meningeal signs are not usually present. Fever is only present in 25% of patients with a brain abscess, so absence of fever does not rule out the diagnosis.

The speed of progression of neurologic symptoms helps to differentiate brain abscesses from ischemia, vascular disease, or neoplasms. Symptom onset over seconds or minutes suggests a vascular event, onset over several hours or days suggests an abscess, and progression of symptoms over weeks to months suggests a neoplasm.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis in an afebrile patient with headache and gradually progressive focal neurologic symptoms that evolve over hours to days is a brain abscess.

B) INCORRECT:

A patient with a brain abscess typically presents with headache and focal neurologic symptoms. These patients may also have altered mental status. Meningeal signs are not usually present. Fever is only present in 25% of patients with a brain abscess, so absence of fever does not rule out the diagnosis.

C) INCORRECT:

The speed of progression of neurologic symptoms helps to differentiate brain abscesses from ischemia, vascular disease, or neoplasms. Symptom onset over seconds or minutes suggests a vascular event, onset over several hours or days suggests an abscess, and progression of symptoms over weeks to months suggests a neoplasm.

D) INCORRECT:

Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy and viral meningitis do not typically result in focal neurologic deficits.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxic-metabolic encephalopathy and viral meningitis do not typically result in focal neurologic deficits.

questions.text:
A 48-year-old man who was previously well is found in his residence with weakness in the left arm and leg, persistent headache, and difficulty speaking. The previous day, he reported fatigue, headache, and a subjective fever. He was also noted to have difficulty typing on a keyboard at work.
He is brought to the emergency department, where he has a fever of 38.9°C, a heart rate of 85 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 125/70 mm Hg. His head and neck examination is unremarkable. Neurologic examination reveals a left-pronator drift, diminished strength in the left leg, and left-sided neglect. Left-sided facial droop and dysarthria are also noted.
The patient is up to date with Covid-19 vaccinations, and testing for SARS-CoV-2 is negative. A contrast-enhanced MRI of the brain is obtained (figure).
In addition to drawing blood cultures and initiating empiric broad-spectrum antibiotic therapy, which one of the following management approaches should be undertaken next for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Open craniotomy with excisional biopsy is associated with greater morbidity than stereotactic aspiration. Therefore, surgical excision is generally reserved for specific situations, such as for multiloculated abscesses or for patients who do not respond to antibiotics and aspiration.

B) INCORRECT:

Radiation therapy is not indicated for treating an infection.

C) INCORRECT:

Antifungal therapy is indicated only in patients who have confirmed fungal infections or risk factors for this type of infection, such as immunosuppression.

D) INCORRECT:

Glucocorticoids should be used only when imaging shows evidence of substantial mass effect; otherwise, they should be avoided.

E) CORRECT:

A patient with neurological deficits related to a brain lesion whose features (documented by MRI) suggest a cerebral abscess should be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics, including anaerobic coverage, because most cerebral abscesses are polymicrobial. Needle aspiration, sometimes guided by CT, may be required for microbiologic diagnosis as well as for therapeutic purposes.

Key learning point: Patients with a suspected brain abscess should be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and stereotactic aspiration.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department after her parents witnessed her having a generalized tonic-clonic seizure at home. The patient has complained of ear pain intermittently during the past month and headaches during the past week. The parents also note that the patient has had high-grade fevers during the past week (maximum temperature, 40°C), increasing somnolence, and three episodes of vomiting. She has no other significant medical history, no family history of seizures, and no other neurologic problems.
On physical examination, the patient has a temperature of 41°C, a heart rate of 120 beats per minute, a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg, and a respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute. She is somnolent but easily arousable to voice. She is able to follow requests from her parents, although she prefers to keep her eyes closed. Her skin has no lesions. Examination of the head, ears, eyes, neck, and throat is unremarkable, with the exception of an otitis media on the right side. Her neck is supple. Her lungs are clear to auscultation. The rest of her examination is unremarkable.
A complete blood count reveals a leukocyte count of 15,500 per mm3 (reference range, 5000–14,500) with 78% polymorphonuclear cells. A rapid HIV test is negative. Blood cultures are sent.
A gadolinium-enhanced MRI of the brain is obtained (figure).
In addition to ceftriaxone, which antimicrobial agent(s) should be started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Tuberculomas are masses in the brain caused by hematogenous spread of Mycobacterium tuberculosis. They are treated with isoniazid, rifampin, pyrazinamide, and ethambutol. Although tuberculoma might be considered in the differential diagnosis for this patient, this condition is much less likely than brain abscess, and empiric treatment should not be limited to covering M. tuberculosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Neurocysticercosis is caused by the pork tapeworm Taeniasolium in its larval stage. Treatment involves antiparasitic therapy such as albendazole. However, high-grade fever would be unlikely in neurocysticercosis, and this condition is less likely than brain abscess in the context of this patient's presentation.

C) CORRECT:

Brain abscess is the most likely diagnosis in this patient, given her otitis media, fever, seizure, altered mental status, and MRI findings. Brain abscesses are focal areas of suppurative intracranial infections and are responsible for approximately 8% of intracranial masses in developing countries and 1% to 2% in developed countries. The causes of brain abscess vary with age. Otitis media is a common infectious source among young children and older adults, whereas preceding paranasal sinusitis is frequent among older children and young adults.

There are currently no national guidelines in the United States for treating brain abscesses in children. Empiric treatment is chosen according to the predisposing condition and likely pathogens. In this patient, the combination of ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and vancomycin should be used. Ceftriaxone targets aerobic and microaerophilic streptococci and Enterobacteriaceae; metronidazole provides coverage of anaerobes including gram-negative bacilli (i.e., Prevotella spp. and Bacteroides spp.); and vancomycin is added for penicillin-resistant pneumococcal infections and to cover Staphylococcus aureus (including methicillin-resistant S. aureus). In addition to antibiotics, neurosurgery should be consulted because needle aspiration or surgical excision is generally used for both diagnosis and treatment.

Key learning point: The empiric treatment for a brain abscess that is likely associated with an ear infection should include ceftriaxone, metronidazole, and vancomycin.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes simplex virus is considered in cases of viral meningitis and encephalitis, and it is treated with acyclovir. This infection would not manifest with a ring-enhancing lesion on imaging.

E) INCORRECT:

Toxoplasma infection in people with HIV can include encephalitis and ring-enhancing brain lesions on imaging. Treatment might include sulfadiazine and pyrimethamine (with leucovorin added to mitigate hematologic adverse effects), but this therapy is not indicated in this patient, who has tested negative for HIV.

questions.text:
A 5-year-old girl is brought to the emergency department for evaluation. Her parents report that she has been feverish and irritable for the past 6 days, has had several bouts of vomiting, and has complained of headache. She had previously been well except for undergoing dental work recently to fill several cavities.
On physical examination, she has a temperature of 40.2°C, a heart rate of 160 beats per minute, and a blood pressure of 90/50 mm Hg. She is lethargic, demonstrates weakness of the left arm, and has a 3/6 systolic ejection murmur heard over the left upper sternal border.
What is the best initial test to diagnose the cause of this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Serum screening for West Nile virus

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient’s altered mental status and focal neurologic deficit are concerning for the presence of a mass lesion that may be causing increased intracranial pressure. Lumbar puncture may precipitate herniation syndrome. Therefore, patients with suspected increased intracranial pressure should undergo imaging before lumbar puncture, to rule out an intracranial mass lesion.

B) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound of the head is the initial imaging modality of choice to detect cerebral infection in neonates and can also be used to assess the size of the ventricles. The images are obtained through the anterior fontanelle and posterior fontanelle. Given that this patient is 5 years old, the fontanelles are likely to be closed, and ultrasound of the head would not be possible.

C) CORRECT:

Children with acute focal neurologic deficits (in this case, left-arm weakness) should undergo immediate medical workup to evaluate for acute stroke or another cerebral lesion. Emergency brain imaging is warranted to assess for a mass, increased intracranial pressure, intracranial infection, and bleeding. CT of the head is widely available and provides fast imaging without the need for sedation. However, the contrast resolution of CT is limited to differential densities, so it may miss subtle differences between gray and white matter in cerebritis of an immature, hypomyelinated brain.

The presence of a heart murmur in this patient suggests the possibility of a congenital cardiac abnormality that may have led to cerebral abscess formation after bacteremia from dental work. After workup and stabilization, this child may require further imaging with a contrast-enhanced brain MRI, which is a valuable diagnostic tool in distinguishing brain abscess from infarct or tumor. Certain MRI sequences — including DWI (diffusion-weighted imaging) and ADC (apparent diffusion coefficient), magnetic resonance spectroscopy, and contrast image sequences — are both sensitive and specific for the diagnosis of cerebral abscess.

Intracranial infections can result from the extension of infection in surrounding structures, such as sinusitis or otitis media, or from hematogenous spread, which is the more likely mechanism in this patient. Children with congenital heart conditions, such as patent foramen ovale or pulmonary arteriovenous fistula, have right-to-left shunting; thus, bloodstream infections in these children may lead to cerebritis and formation of cerebral abscesses. Optimal treatment requires drainage of the abscess in combination with intravenous antibiotics.

Key learning point: The most appropriate test to diagnose an intracranial abscess is CT of the brain.

D) INCORRECT:

West Nile virus infection may be considered if a child presents with fever, encephalopathy, and flaccid weakness after exposure to mosquitoes. Given that this patient’s symptoms occurred in the context of recent dental work, infection with this virus is less likely, and serologic testing would not be the most appropriate next diagnostic test.

E) INCORRECT:

Electroencephalography is useful for patients who present with seizures. However, it would not help in the diagnosis of cerebral abscess.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man with diabetes presents with a 4-day history of progressive headache and difficulty with word finding. His wife notes he has been increasingly confused over the past 24 hours. He had sinus surgery 6 weeks ago for recurrent sinusitis. Physical examination shows mild left-sided facial weakness and difficulty with speech fluency. Vital signs are BP, 145/85; P, 88; T, 37.8°C (100.0°F). Laboratory results show WBC 11,800/μL and CRP 45 mg/L. What is the next most appropriate step in management?

choices.text: Obtain urgent CT head with IV contrast

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Dexamethasone administration is not indicated before obtaining imaging as this patient lacks signs of severe cerebral edema or elevated intracranial pressure.

B) INCORRECT:

While broad-spectrum antibiotics will likely be needed, imaging must be performed first to characterize the suspected lesion, and antibiotics may be deferred in consultation with neurosurgery if diagnostic sampling can occur within 24 hours.

C) INCORRECT:

Lumbar puncture should not be performed before imaging in patients with suspected brain abscess due to the risk of cerebral herniation from mass effect.

D) INCORRECT:

Neurosurgical consultation will be necessary for definitive management, but obtaining imaging first is essential to provide the surgical team with adequate information about the size, location, and characteristics of the suspected abscess.

E) CORRECT:

Correct – CT head with IV contrast is the most appropriate immediate next step. The patient's presentation with focal neurological deficits, recent sinus surgery, and elevated inflammatory markers suggests possible brain abscess. CT with contrast will rapidly identify ring-enhancing lesions and guide further management decisions, including the need for urgent neurosurgical intervention.
